title: How to Make Caramel Syrup

steps.headline: Put the sugar, some of the water, and corn syrup in a pot.
steps.description: Set a small, heavy pot on the stove and put 1 cup (200 g) of granulated sugar into it. Add ⁄4 cup (59 ml) of the water and 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of corn syrup.Did You Know? Corn syrup will prevent the caramel syrup from crystallizing as it's stored. If you don't want to use corn syrup, substitute a squirt of lemon juice or a pinch of cream of tartar. These will also prevent the syrup from crystallizing.

steps.headline: Stir the mixture over low heat.
steps.description: Continue to stir the mixture with a wooden spoon, so the sugar dissolves and the ingredients combine. This should take 2 to 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Cover and boil the syrup for 2 to 3 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the burner to medium and put the lid on the pot. Let the caramel syrup boil for 2 to 3 minutes without uncovering or stirring it. The sugar will start to caramelize as it boils.

steps.headline: Uncover and boil the syrup for 1 to 2 minutes.
steps.description: Use oven mitts to lift away the lid and keep the burner turned to medium. Use the wooden spoon to constantly stir the caramel syrup until it turns a pale brown color. Caramel cooks quickly, which is why it's important to stir it continuously and not walk away from it.

steps.headline: Turn off the burner and remove the pot.
steps.description: To stop the caramel from cooking, turn off the burner and carefully move the pot to a different burner. If you leave the pot on the hot burner, the caramel will continue to cook even though the burner is turned off.

steps.headline: Stir in the remaining ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of water.
steps.description: Slowly stir in the rest of the water so the caramel doesn't splash out or splatter. The water will thin the caramel to make it even more syrupy.

steps.headline: Stir in the vanilla and salt before you cool the syrup.
steps.description: Add 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of vanilla extract and 1 pinch of salt. Stir until they're combined with the caramel syrup. Then let the syrup cool to room temperature before you pour it into a clean storage container. If you prefer a stronger salted caramel flavor, add more salt according to your taste.

steps.headline: Use the caramel syrup in your favorite drinks and cocktails.
steps.description: Try stirring 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 ml) of the syrup into your drink. Then put the container of caramel syrup into the refrigerator. Use it within 2 months for the best flavor. You can also sweeten hot drinks, such as apple cider or hot cocoa, with the caramel syrup.

steps.headline: Melt the butter over medium-high until it begins to bubble.
steps.description: Put 4 tablespoons (56 g) of unsalted butter into a deep pot on the stove. Turn the burner to medium-high and stir the butter occasionally until it melts and starts to bubble just a little. It's important to use a deep pot since the caramel may splatter a little later.

steps.headline: Whisk in the sugar, some of the buttermilk, corn syrup, and salt.
steps.description: Stir in 1 cup (200 g) of granulated sugar until it's dissolved in the melted butter. Then whisk in ⁄3 cup (160 ml) of the buttermilk, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of light corn syrup, and a pinch of salt. Keep whisking until the ingredients are combined.Variation: For an even richer and less tangy flavor, substitute evaporated milk for the buttermilk. The corn syrup will prevent the caramel syrup from crystallizing. If you prefer, substitute a squirt of lemon juice or a pinch of cream of tartar.

steps.headline: Boil the caramel syrup for 8 to 10 minutes.
steps.description: Keep the burner at medium-high heat and stir the syrup occasionally. Let the syrup bubble vigorously until it turns a rich brown color. If the syrup looks like it may boil over, turn the burner down to medium heat.

steps.headline: Turn off the burner and remove the pot.
steps.description: Wear oven mitts and carefully transfer the pot to a cold burner. This will stop the caramel syrup from continuing to cook.

steps.headline: Whisk in ⁄3 cup (79 ml) of buttermilk and the vanilla.
steps.description: Whisk in the remaining buttermilk and 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of vanilla extract. The caramel syrup will bubble up a lot when you add the rest of the buttermilk. Keep whisking until the bubbling dies down and the caramel syrup is smooth.

steps.headline: Simmer the syrup for 3 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Put the pot back on the warm burner and turn the heat on to medium-high again. Let the syrup bubble steadily until it thickens a little. Stir it occasionally as it simmers. Keep in mind that the caramel syrup will thicken a little as it cools off.

steps.headline: Cool the syrup for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Since this caramel syrup will harden a little as it cools, you should use it while it's still warm. Pour it over pancakes, waffles, ice cream, or your favorite dessert.

steps.headline: Store the leftover syrup for up to 2 weeks.
steps.description: Transfer the syrup to an airtight container and refrigerate it for up to 2 weeks.To reheat cold syrup, place some in a dish and microwave it for 30 to 60 seconds or until it's liquid.
